awd_abstract_narration:
Many models in the sciences and engineering lead to mathematical problems about solutions of equations in commuting variables. However, starting with quantum mechanics, a great number of models emerged that led to mathematical problems involving variables that no longer commute. Noncommutative algebra is one of the areas of mathematics that studies those structures. This research project investigates the interrelations between the commutative and noncommutative settings, and the possible ways to study the latter via geometry and combinatorics. The geometric approach attaches structures, called Poisson manifolds, to noncommutative objects. The combinatorial approach studies intricate internal transformations of the objects, called cluster mutations. Both approaches will be used to carry out a detailed study of the properties and symmetries of noncommutative objects. In the opposite direction, the noncommutative objects will be shown to exhibit various forms of rigidity, which in turn will be used to address algebraic, geometric, and combinatorial problems of independent interest. These research activities will be used as the foundation for the training of graduate and undergraduate students and for mentoring mathematics postdocs. 

This research project investigates problems in noncommutative algebra and the relations of these structures to Poisson geometry, representation theory, combinatorics, homological algebra, and noncommutative geometry. The program aims at using techniques from those areas to settle problems in noncommutative algebra, and in the opposite direction, to apply rigidity properties of noncommutative algebras to resolve problems of independent interest to other areas of mathematics. One direction of this program is the description of the automorphism groups and invariants, such as discriminants, of noncommutative algebras via Poisson geometry and cluster algebras. Another direction targets the study of the properties of Nichols algebras and quantum groups by realizing them as cluster algebras. The geometric and combinatorial approaches will be merged in the investigation of the topology of the spectra of quantum function algebras. Noncommutative projective spaces and Calabi-Yau algebras will be studied using techniques from cluster algebras. In the reverse direction, these connections will be used to investigate homological and Poisson geometric properties of cluster algebras.

Outcomes related to Intellectual Merit:

Cluster Algebras were defined by S. Fomin and A. Zelevinsky in groundbreaking works from 2002. Within very short time they started playing a major role in many areas in Mathematics and Mathematical Physics. One of the key open problems in the area was to prove that quantized and classical coordinate rings of important varieties in representation theory have structures of quantum cluster algebras. This is a major step towards understanding the intrinsic structure of their canonical bases in terms of cluster algebras. K. Goodearl and the PI settled several key open problems in this area. They proved that under general axiomatic conditions, a quantum algebra has the structure of an integral quantum cluster algebra. As an application, they constructed integral quantum cluster algebra structures on the quantum unipotent cells associated to all symmetrizable Kac-Moody groups. The PI and Goodearl also found a classical analog of this construction producing classical cluster algebras on the coordinate rings of Poisson varieties satisfying general axiomatic conditions. With the PhD student Eric Bucher, the PI developed a general method for reconstructing the topology of surfaces from the Fomin-Shapiro-Thurston cluster algebras.

In the area of noncommutative projective algebraic geometry, in a series of fundamental works, Artin-Schleter-Tate-van den Bergh classified all noncommutative projective spaces of low dimension. A key role is played by the Sklyanin algebras of dimensions 3 and 4. One of the main open problem from the 1990s was to classify their irreducible representations. This was accomplished in two papers of the PI with C. Walton and X. Wang which completely resolved the 3 and 4 dimensional cases.

Discriminants play a major role in number theory, algebraic geometry and noncommutative algebra. Together with the PhD students J. Levit, B. Nguyen, and K. Trampel, the PI developed general methods for computing discriminants of noncommutative algebras based on Poisson geometry and cluster algebra techniques. These mehods are applicable in wide generality. For instance, the discriminants of the quantum unipotent cells associated to all symmetrizable Kac-Moody groups were explicitly computed as special cases. The PI and K. Brown found an intrinsic relation between the Azumaya locus of noncommutative algebras and their discriminants that allows for an explicit reconstruction of one from the other.

Quantum groups and quantum symmetric pairs play a major role in mathematical physics, representation theory and integrable systems. The PI and S. Kolb defined quantum symmetric pairs in the broad setting of quantum groups built from Nichols algebras. In this wide generality they constructed universal K-matrices. They are solutions of the Reflection Equation and have numerous application to both problems in pure mathematics and mathematical physics. The PI, together with N. Andruskiewitsch and I. Angiono constructed of the structures of Poisson orders on the quantum groups in this broad class, which provides a powerful tool for the future classification of their irreducible representations. As a special case, this method applies to all big quantum supergroups at roots of unity.

One of the main long standing open problems in the area of Orthogonal Polynomials was the matrix Bochner problem for the classification of orthogonal matrix polynomials which are eigenfunctions of a second order differential operator. This problem came from the fundamental work of Bochner from the 1920s which settled the scalar case. The PI and postdoctor R. Casper fully resolved the matrix Bochner problem using methods from noncommutative algebra. They also settled a conjecture from the 1980s claiming that all selfadjoint bispectral functions of ranks 1 and 2 give rise to integral operators which possess a commuting differential operator. This work provides a vast expansion of the collection of integral operators with prolate-spheroidal properties constructed by Landau, Pollak, Slepian, Tracy and Widom.

Outcomes related to Broader Impacts:

The grant provided outstanding opportunities for the education of the next generation of mathematicians. The PI graduated 5 PhD students under this grant: E. Bucher, M. Klukarni, J. Levitt, B. Nguyen, and K. Trampel. All of them went to three-year postdoc positions at prestigious institutions. The PI also mentored the postdoc R. Casper. Many of the outcomes in the intellectual impact part represent joint works of the PI, graduate students and postdoc. The PI also taught many advanced courses for undergraduates who went on to PhD programs in sciences and engineering.

The PI coorganized many conferences which stimulated the development of junior mathematicians and the dissemination of new research. These include a series of US-Mexico Conferences in Representation Theory, Noncommutative Algebra and Categorification, a large international conference titled Representation Theory, Mathematical Physics and Integrable Systems in Luminy, France (June 2018), a special session at the 2018 International Meeting of the American and Chinese Mathematical Societies in Shanghai, China (June 2018), and the 11th Southeastern Lie Theory workshop at LSU (May 2019). The US-Mexico conference series provides oustanding opportunities for mathemticians from underrepresented groups.
